In the medieval era, Barcelona became a major regional hub for politics and religion, distinct from its surroundings, due to its development since Roman times and the formation of the Raval district. The Jewish quarter, known as the Call, was established in Barcelona by 692 and endured until its destruction in 1391 during a xenophobic attack. Enclosed by a wall, the Call had two synagogues, baths, and was segregated from the main city. The Major synagogue now functions as a museum, while the Menor synagogue is currently the parish church of Sant Jaume.

The Jewish quarter, called the Call, existed in Barcelona from 692 until its destruction in 1391 due to xenophobic violence. The Call, Barcelona's Jewish quarter, was replaced with agricultural land after its destruction in 1391, which was made more productive with the construction of the Besòs canal in the mid-10th century. This canal ran parallel to the Strata Francisca, a road that the Franks built as a variant of the Via Augusta to enhance connections with the Carolingian Empire's heartland. The Strata Francisca served this purpose once the threat of Muslim attacks had subsided.

After the threat of Muslim attacks receded, new settlements emerged outside Barcelona's city walls, typically centered around churches and monasteries. This development was aided by the creation of the Besòs canal and the Strata Francisca, which improved connections to the Carolingian Empire's core. After the danger of Muslim attacks diminished, new neighborhoods formed outside Barcelona's city walls, often concentrated around churches. Similarly, the area surrounding Santa Maria del Pi church developed into a neighborhood known as El Pi. These developments were facilitated by the creation of the Besòs canal and the Strata Francisca, which enhanced connections to the Carolingian Empire's heartland. During the post-Muslim era, neighborhoods outside Barcelona's walls grew around churches, landmarks, and monasteries, such as Sant Pau del Camp (914), Sant Antoni Abat (1157), the Carmelites Calçats convent (1292), the priory of Nazareth (1342), and the Montalegre monastery (1362) (Puig, 2013). The Besòs canal and Strata Francisca facilitated connections to the Carolingian Empire's center, promoting these developments. After Barcelona's expansion towards Sant Pau del Camp in the post-Muslim era, the city's growth led to a longer city wall in 1260, stretching 5100 meters and enclosing 1.5 km². Following Barcelona's expansion in the post-Muslim period, a longer city wall was constructed in 1260, enclosing specific zones of influence. In the medieval expansion of Barcelona, the street network was organized in an irregular pattern, and squares were simply widened areas of streets or plots of land created by demolishing buildings, which often served as storage spaces for goods like wheat, wool, or coal. This layout also incorporated the influence of various groups, including religious orders, within the city walls. Defensive structures were constructed outside the city.

In the development of medieval Barcelona, housing typically consisted of "artisan-type" buildings, which featured a ground floor for workshops and one or two stories for residential use. These homes were generally 4 meters wide and 10-12 meters deep, and might include a small garden for growing vegetables. Larger structures were either churches or palaces. This layout was influenced by various groups within the city and featured defensive structures outside the city walls.

In the construction of medieval Barcelona, bigger structures were either churches or palaces, as well as certain institutional buildings such as the Casa de la Ciutat, which served as the seat of the Consell de Cent government and later became City Hall, and the Palau de la Generalitat de Catalunya, which housed the governing body of the Principality. This architectural design was shaped by various urban groups and included defensive systems outside the city walls.

In the construction of medieval Barcelona, large structures were primarily churches, palaces, or institutional buildings, including the Santa Creu hospital and establishments like the Llotja and Drassanes. A significant early urban planning event was the development of Montcada street in 1209, driven by private initiatives.

In 1209, King Peter II allowed Guillem Ramon de Montcada to create Montcada street, which became a wide, straight road connecting Bòria and the sea, filled with grand aristocratic homes. This marked a notable urban planning milestone in medieval Barcelona, driven by private initiatives.

In the 13th century, King Peter II facilitated the development of the Plaça Nova, a spacious area adjacent to the Bishop's Palace and close to Barcelona's cathedral, which, like Montcada street, was an instance of significant urban planning during that time, primarily initiated by private entities and characterized by the construction of large, noble residences.

In the mid-14th century, King Peter II's urban development efforts resulted in the creation of Plaça Nova, a spacious area near Barcelona's cathedral, built by private entities with grand, noble residences. Later, during the 14th and 15th centuries, the city's ongoing growth necessitated the expansion of the walled area, culminating in the construction of the Raval wall.

In the 14th and 15th centuries, King Peter II's urban development initiatives led to the construction of the Raval wall, a larger urban enclosure in Barcelona's western region, encompassing 218 hectares and measuring 6 kilometers in perimeter. In the 14th and 15th centuries, King Peter II's urban development projects resulted in the construction of the Raval wall, which extended Barcelona's western region by 218 hectares and 6 kilometers in perimeter. The expansion began at the Drassanes and continued along the existing ring roads of Sant Pau, Sant Antoni, and down the modern-day Passeig de Lluís Companys, reaching as far as the Santa Clara monastery in the present-day Citadel Park and the sea, following Avinguda Marquès del l'Argentera.

In the time of Barcelona's economic revival during the 15th and 16th centuries, a man-made port was constructed to accommodate the city's thriving mercantile activity, which is surprising because, despite the Catalan trade's prosperity in the Mediterranean, Barcelona lacked a suitable port for the high volume of maritime trade.

During Barcelona's economic upswing in the 15th and 16th centuries, the city, which had previously relied on an abandoned port at the base of Montjuïc and the beach for maritime trade, decided to build a new man-made port in 1438. This was necessary because the deep-draught ships couldn't be directly unloaded at the old port, and cargo handling was done using boats and rope ladders (bastaixos).

In the 15th and 16th centuries, Barcelona decided to construct a new port in 1438, after securing royal approval, as the existing port had limitations in accommodating deep-draught ships. The initial step in building the new port involved sinking a stone-laden ship to establish a foundation for the wall that would link the beach to the Maians Island.

In the mid-to-late 15th century, Barcelona took steps to enhance its new port by strengthening the wall in 1477 and extending it as a breakwater in 1484. The port's size was further increased in the mid-16th century due to the military campaign of Charles I in Tunisia. These improvements aimed to address the limitations of the previous port and accommodate larger ships.

By the end of the 15th century, Barcelona's port expansion was completed, featuring a quay that measured 180 meters long and 12 meters wide. Simultaneously, the seafront from Pla de Palau to La Rambla was reclaimed and transformed into the Passeig del Mar, thereby urbanizing the area. These developments were undertaken to overcome the earlier port's constraints and accommodate larger vessels, with the added benefit of enhancing the city's infrastructure.

The port expansion in Barcelona, finished by the 15th century, included a 180m-long, 12m-wide quay and the transformation of the seafront from Pla de Palau to La Rambla into Passeig del Mar (now Passeig de Colom), thereby urbanizing the area. Additionally, the water supply and sewage system were upgraded, and the role of mestre de les fonts was established to maintain these systems, overseeing mines and fountains. These improvements aimed to address the previous port's limitations, facilitate larger ships, and modernize the city's infrastructure.

By the 15th century, Barcelona's port was expanded with a longer, wider quay and the development of Passeig del Mar, modernizing the seafront and urbanizing the area. The 18th century marked a decline in Barcelona's autonomy following Philip V's victory in the War of Succession, as the Nueva Planta Decree (1716) abolished significant institutions such as the Generalitat, the Corts, and the Consell de Cent, thereby limiting the city's self-governance. This contrasted with the 15th and 17th centuries, when Barcelona experienced substantial infrastructure advancements, including port expansion, improved water supply and sewage systems, paved streets, and new sewers and fountains. The 18th century saw a decrease in Barcelona's autonomy due to Philip V's victory in the War of Succession, which led to the abolition of key institutions like the Corts, the Consell de Cent, and the Generalitat through the Nueva Planta Decree (1716). This resulted in the replacement of the Corts and the Consell de Cent with a military government, and the municipal jurisdiction was restricted to the city, ending the influence the Consell de Cent had in the metropolitan area. During the 18th century, Barcelona experienced a population boom and its economy became increasingly industrialized, culminating in the Industrial Revolution. The Bourbon rule introduced significant military engineering projects, including the construction of Montjuïc castle and the Citadel fortress, which reflected the shift in power and the reduced autonomy of the city's government institutions. The construction of the Citadel during the 18th century in Barcelona led to the demolition of 1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood, rendering 4500 people homeless and without any form of compensation. Additionally, the Rec Comtal was rerouted. This event is a notable example of the increased power of the Bourbon rule and the reduced autonomy of the city's government institutions, as well as a contrast to the previous centuries of infrastructure growth in Barcelona.

The construction of the Citadel during the 18th century, overseen by Jorge Próspero de Verboom, resulted in the demolition of 1200 houses in Barcelona's Ribera neighborhood, displacing 4500 people. This structure, having a pentagonal shape with a moat and an esplanade, represented the growing power of the Bourbons and diminished authority of the city's government institutions. It was ultimately destroyed in the Revolution of 1868.

The Citadel, constructed in the 18th century under Jorge Próspero de Verboom's supervision, led to the demolition of 1200 houses in Barcelona's Ribera neighborhood, displacing 4500 people. Its pentagonal design, surrounded by a moat and esplanade, showcased the Bourbons' increasing power and the city's government institutions' waning authority. The construction of the Citadel in the 18th century under Jorge Próspero de Verboom's supervision resulted in the demolition of 1200 houses in Barcelona's Ribera neighborhood, displacing 4500 people and symbolizing the growing power of the Bourbons. In the 18th century, after the Citadel's construction led to the demolition of 1200 houses and displacement of 4500 people, the Marquis of La Mina commissioned engineer Pedro Martín Cermeño to create the La Barceloneta neighborhood, characterized by a grid of orthogonal streets and elongated house blocks. In the 18th century, the Marquis of La Mina commissioned engineer Pedro Martín Cermeño to develop La Barceloneta, featuring a grid-like layout with elongated house blocks. In the 18th century, there was a shift in the design of private buildings from the traditional, medieval-style "artisan house" to the "multi-family house," characterized by a shared staircase that clearly divided work and living spaces. This transformation was a significant one, as it marked a departure from the previous architectural norms and introduced new ways of organizing domestic and work life.

The redevelopment of La Rambla, taking place from 1776 to 1778, transformed the medieval-style, mixed-use area into a more specialized, divided space. This redevelopment, therefore, changed the way this area functioned, solidifying the division between work and residential zones, which was a growing trend during the 18th century. This shift aligns with the general change in private building design from "artisan houses" to "multi-family houses," which also separated work and living spaces.

The redevelopment of La Rambla in the mid-18th century led to the demolition of its inner wall, realignment of buildings, and addition of a French boulevard-inspired promenade, transforming it from a mixed-use area with theaters and convents to a more specialized space, coinciding with the trend of dividing work and residential zones and the shift in private building design to separate work and living spaces.

The creation of Sant Joan and Gràcia paseos was proposed during the redevelopment of La Rambla, but their construction occurred later, in the early 1900s for Sant Joan and between 1820-1827 for Gràcia, aligning with the broader trend of separating work and residential zones and transforming building design to distinguish work and living spaces.

During the redevelopment of La Rambla, the idea of building Sant Joan and Gràcia paseos was suggested, which happened later in the early 1900s and between 1820-1827, respectively. After the 1868 revolution, Barcelona underwent growth due to the Citadel's demolition and conversion into a public park, which attracted more immigrants and boosted the population to approximately 400,000 by the end of the century. In this context, the industrial era in Barcelona began in 1832 with the establishment of the Bonaplata Factory by Josep Bonaplata, marking the start of chintz printing industrialization in the city.

This was followed by the founding of the La España Industrial complex in 1849 by the Muntadas brothers in the Sants district. The metallurgical industry started to flourish in Barcelona around the same time as the textile industry, with the Nueva Vulcano foundry launching in 1836 at La Barceloneta and La Barcelonesa starting operations in 1841, both driven by the emergence of railroads and steam navigation.

The metallurgical industry in Barcelona developed simultaneously with the textile industry, as seen with the founding of La Barcelonesa in 1841, a precursor to the significant La Maquinista Terrestre y Marítima (1855). This industrial growth led to major modifications in the city's urban planning.

In 2016, a trial project was launched to transform specific sets of city blocks, referred to as "superblocks," which are intermediate areas between the block and the neighborhood. These superblocks aim to reduce vehicle traffic, thereby promoting pedestrian movement, bicycle usage, and public transportation. In 2016, the initial trial of the superblock project occurred in Poblenou, covering nine city blocks. The project involved altering traffic signs, restricting straight-line vehicle movement, and allowing cars to enter only by turning at intersections with a speed limit of 10 km/h, ultimately encouraging pedestrian and bicycle traffic and providing spaces for leisure and public facilities.
